Dear Sheffield City Council,
I would like the following information :
In the last 12 months how many high risk dv ppns were received?
How many was a child present?
How many strategy discussions took place?
How many led to a S47?
How many subjects of the S47 were 17 years old and over eg between 17 and 18 years old?
How many were seen within 24 hours?
How many was the perpetrator already on remand?
How many were the child of the victim? (Not perpetrators child)
How many were the child of the perpetrator?
How many included children living in other households eg children of perpetrator?
Why aren’t children of perpetrators who have contact not deemed to be at the same level of risk as the child of the victim? Even when the perpetrator doesn’t live with the victim?
How many 17 year olds were placed on child protection plans in the last 12 months due to a domestic violence incident which the child didn’t witness? Same for CIN plans?
What were the reasons?
How many 17 year olds were placed on CIN plans in the last 12 months and the reasons?
Yours faithfully,
Charlotte Reynolds

Dear Charlotte Reynolds,
Thank you for your request for information relating to S47 assessments and
outcomes which we received on 12/12/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. In the last 12 months how many high risk dv ppns were received?
• 1086
• CSC would only get DV Notices when a child is present.
2. How many was a child present?
• By definition all DV Notices are received because a child is present
3. How many strategy discussions took place?
• 163 - Of the above High Risk DV Notices
4. How many led to a S47?
• 137 - Of the above Strategy Discussions
5. How many subjects of the S47 were 17 years old and over eg between 17
and 18 years old?
• 7 - Of the above S47s
6. How many were seen within 24 hours?
• All should have a visit within 24 hours of a strategy discussion.
7. How many was the perpetrator already on remand?
The information you have requested is exempt from disclosure under section
12 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000. Sheffield City Council does
hold the information you have requested. However, we do not record the
information in a format that allows us to produce an electronic report of
this. Therefore, we would have to carry out a manual search of our
records. We estimate that we would need to search 1086 records and that it
would take 15 minutes to search each record. Therefore, it would take us
271 hours to collate the information, which is more than the cost limit of
18 hours or £450 specified in the [1]Freedom of Information and Data
Protection (Appropriate Limit and Fees) Regulations 2004 (SI 2004 No.
3244).
Under section 16 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance to requesters. If you would like to narrow
down the focus of your request, we would be happy to process your revised
request as a new request for information under the Freedom of Information
Act 2000.
8. How many were the child of the victim? (Not perpetrators child) How
many were the child of the perpetrator?
• We do not hold this information in a reportable format – please see
response above.
9. How many included children living in other households eg children of
perpetrator?
• We do not hold this information in a reportable format – please see
response above.
10. Why aren’t children of perpetrators who have contact not deemed to be
at the same level of risk as the child of the victim? Even when the
perpetrator doesn’t live with the victim.
• Each child plan is specific to that child, there is not a different
threshold for children having contact.
11. A How many 17-year-olds were placed on child protection plans in the
last 12 months due to a domestic violence incident which the child
didn’t witness?
• None of the 7 from Question 5 had a CP Plan
Same for CIN plans?
• 15 x 17-year-olds were put on a CIN Plan after a DV Notice was
received by the Hub.
12. How many 17-year-olds were placed on CIN plans in the last 12 months
and the reasons?
Reason Plans
N1 - Abuse or neglect 149
N2 - Child's Disability 3
N4 - Family in acute stress 22
N5 - Family dysfunction 30
N6 - Socially Unacceptable Behaviour 7
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains

If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your

If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you

for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear FOI,
There have been a number of high risk domestic abuse cases being reported in the press recently, which has led to widespread debates around barriers to reporting abuse. Many victims who have children cite fear of childrens services as a barrier. A high number of those have felt let down by children’s services and feel that social care viewed the victim as a risk to the child for “failure to protect” especially if did not leave straight away or did not report some incidents straight away.
There appears to be a culture of placing responsibility on the victim and shifting away from the perpetrator and a clear lack of understanding from social care regarding the complexities of this issue and also the safety implications for leaving an abusive relationship.
In a high proportion of cases where the victim already has a child and enters into a relationship with a partner who also already has a child, and that later becomes abusive it is only the victims child subject to intrusive assessment and the perpetrators child is not. This leads victims to form a view that social care see them as the risk rather than the perpetrator and some even feel there is a victim blaming culture apparent.
I have been informed of several cases where there has been a significant incident and it is only the victims child who has been subject to child protection measures, which seems to support the experiences of many victims.
This has been the case even when no children were present neither victims nor perpetrators. Very often a victims child will have no future ongoing contact with the victims child but will almost certainly continue to have some form of contact with their own.
In order to learn more about this matter I would like you to provide me with information on S47’s carried out and if children living in other households are included eg when the perpetrator has other children with previous partners.
It would be helpful for specific numbers where this has or has not happened.
Any information you could provide me with would be useful for my research.
Yours sincerely,
Lottie40
